This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

cell.p:
EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM
ALEXANDRIA, PORT SAID, AND SUEZ,
TO
NAPLES, MARSEILLES,
GENOA, SOUTHAMPTON, ANTWERP,
BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,
EASTERN ASIA, AUSTRALIA Etc.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Oruba" will leave Suez about October 5
R.M.S "Ophir" will leave Suez about October 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said October 23
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said October 8
Passengers returning by the Line obtain one-third rebate off the above fares if leaving England before the end of October.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-906

div.head: Fatal Accident
div.p: A native labourer was overwhelmed by an avalanche of earth and suffocated at Bab Sharki, Alexandria, yesterday.

div.head: Connaught House Y.W.C.A.
div.p: On Thursday February 1, at 5 p.m., a lecture will be given at Connaught House by Mrs. Lewis, LL D., D.D., on one of the earliest manrscripts of the Gospels.

div.head: The Kaiser's Birthday.
div.p: The German colonies at Alexandria and Cairo celebrated the anniversary of the Kaiser's birthday with the loyalty and functions usual on this occasion. The Kaiser was born on January 27, 1859.

div.head: The Bourse.
div.p: The concessionnaire of the café of the Alexandria Bourse is now paying to the Bourse Company a rent of £400 a year, but we hear that the committee of the company have received an offer of £1,000 per annum for the café.

div.head: Tram Accident
div.p: A native boy, 9 years of age, was run over by a tram at Gabbari yesterday afternoon. A lively scrimmage aftewards ensued, for the youth's friends and relations besieged the tram and belaboured the tram-driver so severely that he will be in the doctor's hands for some days to come.

div.head: A New Egyptian Company.
div.p: It is reported from Brussels, & London contemporary states, that shortly an Egyptian company will be promoted under the name of the Cairo Metropolitan Electric Railway and Heliopolis Oasis Company, for the purpose of working a concession granted to Boghos Pacha and M. Empain. The capital of 15,000,000 f. will be supplied by a syndicate in which Egyptian, English, and to a smaller extent, Belgian capitalists are interested.

div.head: P, W. D. Salaries.
div.p: There have been a large number of increases of salary among the officials of the Irrigation Service of the Public Works Department. The following are the recipients with the amounts to which their salaries have been raised : Mr. John Langley and Ismail Pacha Sirry, L. E. 1,200 ; Hossein Bey Wassif, L. E. 800 ; Mr. J. W. Waghorn, Abdalla Bey Wahbi, and Mr. Mason, L. E. 600 ; Mr. E. W Buckley. Mr. J. F. Brooke, Mr. A. Morcom, and Mr. R. C. Moser, L. E. 480.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Automatic Trading Co.
div.p: Last week, at the Mansion House, before Sir Horatio Davies, Stuart Dixon Stubbs Ross, 38, of 18, Thicket-road, Anerley, and George Bertram Ross, 35, of the same address, general merchants, and brothers, were charged, on remand, with combining together to acquire by false pretences moneys and securities of such persons as should become shareholders in the Anglo-Egyptian Automatic Trading Company (Limited), and in pursuance thereof did obtain £525 17s 6d from Mr. J. G. Prentice. Stuart. D. S. Ross was farther charged with obtaining by false pretences the sum of £648 7s. 6d from Mr. John Edward Champneys. Defendants were again remanded on bail, which was immediately forthcoming

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Countess of Enniskillen left on Thursday to join Lord de Clifford's party up the Nile. They are expected back again at the Savoy on February 8.
Lady Delamere left Cairo on Tharsday and is returning to England.
Sir Elwin Palmer passed an agitated night. His general condition is not as good as yesterday, and his heart is weaker.
Mr. and Mrs. Albert Blaschke are amongst the latest arrivals at Shepheard's. Mr. Blaschke is a member of the firm of S. Bleichröder, the well-known bankers of Berlin.
Mr. Constantine Meimarachi managing director of Walker and Meimarachi, Limited, arrived last night from Cairo and will remain at Alexandria for about three days.
The Khedive has conferred the grade of Mutamaiz on Halil Bey Kamal, an official in the Ministry of Finance, and the Sanieh on Girgis Bey Antoun, of the Administration of State Railways.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.)
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL,
div.p: CAIRO
NOTED FOR ITS EXCELLENT CUISINE.
ELECTRIC LIGHT. LIFT.
Special terms for officers of the Army of Occupation and Government Officials.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d'Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION.

div.head: OPENING OF THE NILE-RED SEA RAILWAY
TODAY'S CEREMONY - DETAILED DESCRIPTION
Interesting Speech by Lord Cromer.
div.p: Arrival of the Dakahlieh.

The S.S. Dakahlieh arrived at Port Sudan with the official visitors and Press representatives who are to attend the inauguration of the Nile Red Sea Railway at 9.45 a.m. The weather is breezy and the Dakahlieh had a splendid passage all the way. And here I wish to place on record the great hospitality with which all on board were treated by the officials of the Sudan Government and the officers of the Khedival Mail Line. The detachment of the Royal Berkshire Regiment, which had been brought from Khrtoum, is camped on the north side of the channel where H. M. S. Diana is anchored. All the buildings in the town are covered with flags, and it is evident that great preparations have been made for to-morrow's ceremony. The members of the Legislative Council who are guests of the Sudan Government are all in good health and spirits.
(FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT).
Port Sudan Friday, 3.40 p.m.
Viewing the Town,

This morning the members of the Legislative Council and the representatives of the Press were taken over H. M. S. Diana. Afterwards the party landed and went round the town in a steam train, visiting among other places the Pulsometer Company's works, which supply water to the town. Though it mainly consists of wooden houses, the town is obviously growing fast, and miles of streets have been marked ont. The Gouvernorat, Quarantine, Customs, and other official buildings are rapidly approaching completion.
The 2.45 train came in from Suakin full of natives, including many merchants. A war dance will be given this evening.
Lord Cromer has not yet arrived, the train being late. H.E. the Sirdar and Lady Wingate are already here,
The harbonr, though small, looks very good and is thought highly of by the offisers of H.M. S. Diana.
(FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT).
Port Sudan, Friday, 7 p.m.
An Entertainment

The members of the Legislative Council and the Press representatives were invited by Kaimakam Kennedy Bey and Bimbashi Kelly to tea in the engineers' mess. H. E. the Sirdar, Lady Wingate, Sir R Slatin Pacha, and many others were present. The great features of the afternoon were a camel race for Hadendowa, which was won by a small boy, and Diluka and other tribal dances performed by scores of Hadendowa blacks and Arabs. A most pleasant afternoon was spent.
(FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT).
PORT SUDAN, Friday, 11 p.m.
Lord Cromer's Arrival,

Lord Cromer's train steamed in some hours late, drawing up before the special landing place, where a guard of honour consisting of three officers and 100 rank and file of the 6th Battalion E.A was drawn up with the Sudanese Infantry band. The Egyptian Artillery fired a salute of 21 guns as Lord Cromer left the train and was immediately greeted by the Governor General of the Sudan. The guard of honour, which looked very smart and workmanlike, presented arms, and the Sudanese band played the British National Anthem.

The cause of the delay to the train by which Lord Cromer and party travelled was over-heated bearings. The result was that the inspection of the port, which was to have taken place place this afternoon, had to be postponed until after the inauguration ceremony to-morrow.
Harbour Illuminated.

The official visitors and Press representatives returned on board the Dakahlieh at nightfall, being accommodated on board for the night. All the veseels in the harbor were illuminated, the display made by H. M. S. Diana being remarkably fine. A display of fireworks also took place on the Dakahlieh, and altogether the day proved most enjoyable and successful.
(From OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT).
Port Sudan, Saturday, 10 a.m.
The Proceedings Begin.

At 7 o'clock this morning, Lord Cromer officially opened the Nile Red-Sea Railway. His Lordship left his saloon in the train at 6.55 a.m. and proceeded to the special enclosure, accompanied by Sir Vincent Corbett, Mr. Higgins, and party. The Governor-General with the Captain and Commander of H.M.S. Diana, the Director and Assistant Director of Railways, the Director of Works and Lieut. Kelly, R.E., the Governor of the Red Sea Pronvince and Inspector of Port Sudan, and members of the staff met Lord Cromer at the entrance and conducted him into the enclosure. As Lord Cromer arrived in front of the tents the flags were broken, the guards of honour presented arms, and the band played the Royal and Khedivial Anthems. A salute of 21 guns was also fired by H.M.S. Diana on the signal of the flags breaking. The guards of honour shouldered arms on the conclusion of the Khedivial Anthem, and then Lord Cromer inspected the guards of hononr, which were furnished by H.M.S. Diana, the 6th Battalion Egyptian Army, and the Royal Berkshire Regiment. The band in attendance was that of the Sudanese Infantry. The British guards were drawn up on the north side of the special enclosure and the Egyptian guard on the south side. The ground was kept by other parties landed for the purpose from H M.S. Diana.
Governor-General's Speech,
The inaugaral proceedings began by the Governor General making the following address :

My Lord,- It is with great pleasure that, on this auspicions occasion, I welcome your lordship to the Sudan, both on my own behalf and on that of the military and civil officials of the Sudan Government, and of the Ulema, Sheikhs, notables, and people of this country. It is indeed, peculiarly fitting that the opening ceremony of this railway, which connects the Red Sea with the River Nile, should be performed by your lordship, representing as you do, for that purpose, his Majesty King Edward VII. and his Highness Abbas Helmy Pasha II., Khedive of Egypt. Since this country was first reconquered, you have kept steadily in view the absolute necessity, if the Sudan was ever to attain a high degree of prosperity, of establishing communication with the outer world by means more rapid and less costly than those afforded by the Nile. To this end, as we are all aware, you have devoted much thought and many years of patient labour, and I am happy to be able to congratulate you to-day on this visible sign of the success which has attended your efforts. We heartily welcome also the presence of Sir Vincent Corbett, the Financial Adviser to H.H. the Khedive, to whom and to Sir William Garstin we owe so much for the valuable advice and assistance they have always so readily accorded. The Sudan has indead every reason to be grateful for the unfailing support extended to it by the high officials of the Khedive's Government, and I would take this opportunity to tender to his Highness--whose enforced absence from this ceremony is deeply regretted by all--and to his Council of Ministers, my respectful thanks for the grest interest which they have from the outset displayed in the construction of the new line. Again, I desire to extend, on behalf of the Sudan Government, a hearty welcome to those members of the Egyptian Legislative Council who have honoured us with their presence here. We rejoice to see them in the Sudan and they may rest assured that we shall do our utmost to make their stay a pleasant one, and to show them, in the short time at their disposal, the result of our efforts to carry out tbe work of civilisation and progress. It only remains for me to bring to your lordship's notice the very capable manner in which the construction of this new railway has been planned and execated by Lieut-Col. Macauley, assisted by his staff. The manner in which, under his able direction, the British, Egyptian, and Sudanese officers and officials, the men of the Railway Battalion, and the native labourers have performed their duties under very trying climatic conditions, is beyond praise, and the work has been completed in a considerably shorter time than was originally thought possible. I will call upon Colonel Macauley to briefly describe the principal points of interest in connection with the railway construction, and will also ask him to bring offically to your lordship's notice the names of those officers and officials who have rendered him special assistance in his difficult and arduous tark, which names it has already been my pleasant daty to submit to his Highness the Khedive. At the close of Col. Macauley's remarks I shall have the honour to invite your lordship to declare the Red Sea-Nile Railway open to traffic.
Macauley Bey's Speech.
Macauley Bey then addressed Lord Cromer in the following terms :

My Lord, --The new route from Khartoum to the sea by the Nile--Red Sea Railway is 900 miles shorter than the old Nile route. The length of the line from Sal-lom junction to Port Sudan is 21 miles, making a total of 331 miles of main line. There are 25 miles of sidings. The cost of constructing the line was L.E. 1,375 000. This figure includes the cost of bridging and some other work which is not yet finished. The cost works out at L.E. 4,150 per mile of main line. Work on the main line at Suakin began in August, 1904, and railway communication between the Nile and the Red Sea was opened in October, 1905. I am much indebted to Captain Midwinter and his staff for the work done at the Atbara end under diffioult conditions. The line was laid on the telescopic system. Owing to the insufficiency of the local water supply, it has been necessary to obtain all water for working parties and most of the water for bridges, buildings, and locomotives, by distilling sea water; all water had to be carried up the line in special tank wagons. While a temporary quay and some workshops, offices, etc., were being prepared at Suakin, an experiment was made with some of the Arab tribes near Suakin to see if they would do the earthwork for the line. They showed little predilection for regular work however, and although a second attempt was made when the actual construction of the main line began it was found difficult to get them to do much earthwork. Men were accordingly brought over from the Nile valley, and the men have worked very well. They have been on piece-work. I desire to mention that I received very valuable advice from Mr. Bakewell, C.E., regarding the general course and construction of the line, and especially in the matter of bridging. I wish to express my thanks to all the staff for the hard work they have done during the construction of the line and I would specially mention : in connection with the control of the Port at Suakin, Lieut. W. B. Dewry, Royal Navy; in connection with the construction of the railway, El Miralai Mahmoud Bey Kheirallah, Capt. W. E. Longfield, R.E.; Capt. M. E. Sowerby, R.E., Lieat. S. F. Newcombe, R. E., Lieut. P. C. Lord, R.E., Mr. C. E. Hickley, the Hon. A. Pelham, Mr. R. W. Windham, El Saghkolaghasi Ali Eff. Shanki, Sagh. Hussein Eff. Yasri, Yuzbashi Hassanein Eff. Rifat, and Yozbashi Mohamed Eff. Ali. The following have also done excellent work in connection with this railway but as they are, if anything, more closely identified with the new railway from Abou Hamed to Kareima their names will again be brought before his Excellency the Governor-General on the occasion of the opening of that line : Capt. F. C. Midwinter, D.S.O, Royal Engineers; Mr. C. Hodgson, Mr. G. B. Macpherson Grant, Mr. H. V. Hawkins, El Saghkolaghasi Mohamed Eff. Fadil, and Ibrahim Eff. Es Sayyid. In conclusion, I beg to thank your lordship, Sir Reginald Wingate, Sir William Garstin, and Sir Vincent Corbett for all the help, kindness, and consideration which has been accorded to me during the execution of the work.
Lord Cromer's Speech.
Lord Cromer made the following speech in reply :

Sir Reginald Wingate and Gentlemen, The first observation which I have to make is, to express my great regret, - which I am sure is shared by all present, - that his Highness the Khedive was unable to attend in order to preside at the ceremony of to-day. I wish alsó to preface my remarks by one further observation of personal character. The honours of to-day, Gentlemen, belong to Colonel Macauley, and his very capable and efficient staff, amongst whom I may especially mention the names of Captain Midwinter and Capt. Longfield, of the Royal Engineers, as also Kaimakam Mehmoud Bey Kheirallah. To have constructed 325 miles of railway in 14 months, under such climatic conditions as those which obtain in the Sudan, is a very remarkable achievement. I wish to take this opportunity, on behalf of the British and of the Egyptian Governments, of expressing my very high appreciation of the zeal and intelligence which have been shown in the execution of this important work. I may add that the cost has been very moderate. It has amounted to not more than L.E. 1,400,000. I now turn to the more public aspects of the railway. Without doubt, of late years a great deal has been done in the Sudan. Order and tranquillity everywhere prevail. A fiscal system has been introduced which is adapted to the needs and requirements of the country. Schools and law courts have been established. It is, however, none the less true to say that the serious development of the Sudan commences from today. So long as the country was separated from the rest of the world by a waste of burning desert, and so long as communication could only be kept up by a line of railway and river steamers over a distance of 1,200 miles--for that is the distance from the mouth of the Atbara to Alexandria--any very rapid progress was out of the question. Colonel Macauley, in the note which we have just heard read, has explained that the distance from Berber to the sea will now be shortened by nearly 900 mile. Fears have been occasionally expressed that the opening of this railway might do harm to Egypt, and it has therefore been urged that the resources of Egypt should not be employed in its construction. I am glad to observe that these complaints are gradually dying out. It cannot be too clearly understood that the construction of this railway will not divert any existing trade to any considerable extent. It will create a trade, which, unless the railway were made, could never exist. For the rest, I may observe that the presence here to-day of several of the most distinguished members of the Egyptian Legislative Council is in itself a sufficient proof that the authorized representatives of the Egyptian people do not share the fears to which I have alluded. My own opinion on this subject has always been very clear, and has been frequently expressed. In the first place, I always regard with a certain amount of suspicion any argument based upon the necessity of keeping one locality--or perhaps in this case I should say a whole continent--in a backward condition, in order that some other locality should prosper. In the second place, more especially since the appearance of Sir W. Garstin's epoch-making report, it has been demonstrated with mathematical precision that the material prosperity of Egypt is intimately bound up with that of the Sudan. It is the river Nile which connects them; and it is certain that any large works undertaken in the future to benefit Egypt must be constructed, not in Egypt proper, but in the upper regions of the Nile Valley. This railway is, therefore, the first and preliminary step in the gradual execution of a large scheme for the construction of works of public utility. It is the main artery of communication which will open out the Sudan to the world. But before the country can gain the fall advantages to be derived from this undertaking, further works must be constructed. Some, indeed, have already commenced. The port at which I am now speaking is springing into existence. Before many months have elapsed, I hope that the railway from Kareima to Abu Hamed will be opened and will thus put the wealthy province of Dongola in direct communication with the sea. Irrigation works are about to be undertaken to utilise the waters of the Gash, and thus fertilize the plains in the neighbourhood of Kassala, Borings are about to be made with a view to the constructioa of a bridge over both the Blue and White Niles at Khartoum. Railway surveys are being undertaken with the ultimate object of bringing Kassala into communication with the main line, of extending the railway up the left bank of the Blue Nile, and of enabling the gum of Kordofan to fiad a ready market by bringing El Obeid into direct communication with Omdurman. It is not to be supposed that all these works will be at once remunerative. Undertakings of this sort, cannot possibly pay in the first few years of their existence ; but that they will ultimately prove remunerative I have not the smallest doubt. I can, therefore, confidently recommend the taxpayers of Egypt to "Trust on, and think to-morrow will repay." I need hardly say that the measures to which I have alluded and which only form the preliminary steps to the execution of Sir William Garstin's vast programme, will take years to accomplish. At my time of life, I can only hope to stand on the top of an administrative Mount Pisgah. I can scarcely hope to enter the promised land. I wish, however, gentlemen, very strongly to impress upon you that the execution of this programme--and I may add, both the general and local policy of the British Government in Egypt and the Sudan--does not in the least depend upon the individuals who have to carry it out. It will be found, I am well convinced, wholly independent of ministerial changes in England, and of changes in the executive on the spot. If I were to leave Bgypt—which I have not the least intention of doing, so long as my health and strength endor--or if Sir Reginald Wingate were to leave the Sudan--and I trust a very long time will elapse before he does so--all that need be said would be, "Il n'y a qu'un Anglais de moins." In conformity, not only with the Anglo-Eyptian Convention of 1899, but also with the liberal policy persistently pursued by the British Government in these matters, this port and railway will be open on equal terms to the trade of all the world. There will be no differential rates or duties to favour the trade of any one nation. But, gentlemen, it has to be remembered, that though I do not doubt that, the opening up of the Soudan will bring with it many of the blessings of civilization, there is an inevitable risk that it will bring in its train some of the incidents which appear to be the accompaniment, and are certainly the shame, of the civilisation of the West. The railway will carry the legitimate trader, the tourist, the scientist, and the philanthropist. It will also, possibly, convey to the Soudan the drinkseller, the usurer, and the commercial adventurer. I may say at once that I do not believe that any heroic or arbitrary measures are at all desirable in order to keep this latter class of society out of the country. But they may be combated by other means. Sound agricultural banks may compete with the usurer. Wise legislation may put some check on the excessive sale of drink. Care and judgment in the disposal of Government lands may do a great deal to nullify any harm done by the mere company-monger. I do not doubt that all these subjects will receive the full attention of Sir Reginald Wingate, of whose past services to the Sudan I cannot speak in terms of too high praise. There is yet one further point to which I wish to allude. The transfer of the terminus of the railway from Suakin to Port Sudan has, I am aware, been a disappointment to the inhabitants of the former place. That their interests demand consideration at the hands of the Government, I fully admit. Residents in Suakin will therefore receive favourable treatment in the allotment of the lands for the new town of Port Sudan, except, of course, those who have merely bought land for speculative purposes. I cannot hold out any hope that this latter class will be esceptionally treated. If they gamble in land, they must expect occasionally to lose. Under the authority which I have received from his Majesty King Edward VII. and his Highness the Khedive, I now declare the railway from Port Sudan to Berber open.

Lord Cromer's speeeh was afterwards read out in Arabic by Shahin Bey Ghirgis (Arabic Secretary) Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pacha then shortly explained in simple vernacular to the assembled merchants, and to the omdehs and sheikhs and people of nomad Arabs present, the effect the new railway will have in improving their trade and local conditions, after which Lord Cromer formally opened the line, the guards of honour presenting arms, and the band playing the Royal and Khedivial Anthems.
Then followeł an eloquent speech by Charrarbi Pacha in Arabic. Your correspondent is no judge of Arabic rhetoric, but qualified listeners spoke most highly of the Pacha's speech.
The speeches over, the Governor-General presented to Lord Cromer the members of the railway staff engaged in the construction of the new line

The proceedings then terminated. The guard of honour saluted as Lord Cromer left the enclosure. The British and Egyptian flags were lowered, and on this signal being given H. M. S. Diada fired a salute of 31 guns.

div.head: THE ELECTIONS. DEFEAT OF MR. CROOKSHANK.
div.p: To-day's Liberal gains number seven, the Unionists' one. The Government undergoes no change in ten constituencies and the Unionists in four. Mr. Crookshank, brother of Crookshank Pacha, has been defeated by 262 votes.

div.head: NEW APPEAL JUDGE.
div.p: Mr. J. Fletcher Moulton, K.C, F.R.S. the great anthority on patent law and a well-known Liberal barrister, has been appointed a Lord Justice of the Court of Appeal.

div.head: GRESHAM LIFE ASSURANCE CO. IMPORTANT JUDGMENT.
div.p: This morning the Mixed Court of 1st Instance at Cairo pronounced judgment in the case brought by Mr. Otto Schmidt, late general agent of the Gresham Life Assurance Society, Limited, at Alexandria, against that Society for rupture of contract. The Court ordered the Gresham to pay an indemnity of LE. 1.000 plus commissions on business of which no account had been rendered by the Society.

div.head: EXTENSION OF PENNY POSTAGE
div.p: With effect from the 1st February next, the postage on letters for Malta and Cyprus will be reduced and fixed at 5 milliomes for every 15 grammes or fraction thereof.
Up to the present penny postage has been adopted with the United Kingdom, New Zealand, British India (including Aden), the Straits Settlements, Malta, and Cyprus.

div.head: CONSULAR APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: Mr. George Pollard Davey, at present the British Consal at Jeddah, has been appointed to be his Majesty's Consul at Damascus.
Mr. John Francis Jones has been appointed to be his Majesty's Consul for the Eastern Coast of the Red Ses, to reside at Jeddah.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive is leaving Montazah for Cairo this evening.

div.head: THE DELTA CANALS.
div.p: In superression of the notice previously issued on the subject navigation companies, and others interested, are invited to note that in the rules for the regulation of navigation now being drawn up by the Public Works Department, it is proposed to fix the limiting dimensions of craft plying on the navigable canals in the Delta, as regards thair maximum length, maximum beam, maximum draft, respectively: steam or motor barges, 35.00,6.8, 2.0 ; cargo barges, 25.00, 6.0, 2.0; tugs, 20.00, 4.0, 2.0; country boats, 92.00, 6.0, 2.0.
The dimensions have been modified as above in order to meet the wishes of the owners of barges so far as may be possible.
It is only the main canals such as :- the Rayah Menufia, the Bagouris, the Mahmudia, the Rayah Tewfiki and the Mansuira, which are capable of passing craft of the above dimensions.
Many of the locks on the other navigable canals are too small to accommodate craft of this size, and, during summer, the depth of water in the tail reaches, often falls much below 1 metres.

Even in the main canals a depth of 2.0 metres can by no means always be depended on, and during seasons of low supply owners will run the risk of grounding barges or boats if they lead them so as to make their draft reach or nearly reach the limiting value of 2.0 metres.

div.head: THEATRE ALHAMBRA
div.p: Dans la soirée donnée hier à l'Alhambra au bénéfice de Mlle Chantenay, cette excellente artiste a obtenu un grand succès dans le rôle d'Irma da "Grand Mogol." Elle y a été éblouissante de grâce et d'entrain. On pourrait en dire autant de la princesse Bengaline, Mlle Nolba, qui a été surtout remarquée dans la scène de la séduction. M. La Bany a été fort admiré dans le rôle de Mignapour, ainsi que M. Crépy dans celui de Joquelet. La note comique était donnée par MM. de la Freydière et Simon, le premier en Nicobar et le second en Crakson.
Demain, à 4 h. p.m. 'La Fille de Mme Angot"; le soir "Le Grand Mogol."

div.head: STOCKS AND SHARES
div.p: Furnished by Reid & Bernard 10, St. Marks Buildings, Alexandria, and Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, who undertake the sale and purchase of Stocks and Shares, on the local Bourse and also on the London Stock Exchange.
